title: Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19)
description: This is an emerging, rapidly evolving situation. The Alabama Department of Public Health (ADPH) and the CDC are providing updated information and guidance as it becomes available.
cleaned_text: HELP? Having finding what you are looking for? Use our [A to Z Index](../about/az-index.html) or [Contact Us](../about/contact.html). Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) The Alabama Department of Public Health (ADPH) continues to provide guidance as well as testing and vaccines to Alabamians after the COVID-19 Public Health Emergency, which ended May 11, 2023. The ending of the Public Health Emergency does not change which conditions or laboratory results are mandated to be reported in Alabama. SARS-CoV-2 results and COVID-19 diagnoses are still reportable in Alabama. [Read our full news release for more](https://www.alabamapublichealth.gov/blog/2023/05/nr-09.html). Protect Against COVID-19 The best way to prevent illness is to avoid being exposed to it. Learn more on [How to Protect Yourself and Others](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prevent-getting-sick/prevention.html) and [Knowing Your Exposure Risk](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/your-health/risks-exposure.html) from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). For the best protection against severe [COVID symptoms](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/symptoms-testing/symptoms.html), [stay up to date on your vaccines](vaccine.html) and get tested if you develop cold or flu-like symptoms. Home Tests As of June 1, 2023, ordering through the [COVIDtests.gov](https://www.covid.gov/tests) program has been suspended to preserve the remaining supply. The program is no longer accepting orders. Before you throw out "expired" tests, [check to see if your COVID-19 tests' expiration dates have been extended](https://www.fda.gov/medical-devices/coronavirus-covid-19-and-medical-devices/home-otc-covid-19-diagnostic-tests#list). [Download When To Take An At-Home COVID-19 Test](assets/cov-at-home-test-result.pdf) | [En Español](assets/cov-at-home-test-result-sp.pdf) Testing Sites Search for a location that offers no-cost COVID-19 testing at [testinglocator.cdc.gov](https://testinglocator.cdc.gov/). For clinic times at county health departments, visit [Locations](../about/locations.html). Test to Treat Sites After testing positive and seeing a healthcare provider, eligible individuals going to Test to Treat sites can immediately receive a prescription for oral COVID-19 treatment and fill that prescription - all at one location in a participating site. A [Test to Treat Locator](https://covid-19-test-to-treat-locator-dhhs.hub.arcgis.com/) is available to help find participating sites. Learn more at [Test to Treat](https://aspr.hhs.gov/TestToTreat/Pages/default.aspx). What to Do If You Were Exposed If you have tested positive or are showing symptoms of COVID-19, isolate immediately and [check the CDC's Isolation and Exposure Calculator for the next steps](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/your-health/if-you-were-exposed.html). Traveler's Health If you are traveling within the United States or abroad, be sure you know the [travel requirements for COVID-19](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/index.html) from the Centers for Disease Prevention and Control (CDC).
